questions.question: What is the following logo used to indicate in biomedical waste management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Radiation hazard Explanation: Biohazard or Biomedical waste or Biochemical waste includes chemicals used in labs, pathogens, viruses, bacteria, and other microorganisms that pose health risks. Radiation Hazard: Involves materials emitting ionising radiation that can cause health issues like cancer and tissue damage. Recycling: Refers to the process of converting waste materials into reusable resources to reduce

questions.question: Which color-coded container is used for disposing of infectious biomedical waste, such as contaminated dressings or swabs?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Yellow Explanation: As contaminated dressings or swabs are infectious, they fall into the yellow category. Colour Waste Type Type of bag or container to be used Method of disposal Yellow All infectious waste. Human anatomical waste. Animal anatomical waste Soiled waste (contaminated with blood, body fluids, dressings and swabs, blood bags ). Expired or discarded medicines Chemical waste. Microbiological and other clinical laboratory waste. Yellow coloured non chlorinated plastic bags. Incineration Plasma pyrolysis Deep burial Red Contaminated waste (recyclable) : Tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags , syringes (without needles), vacutainers and gloves. Red coloured non chlorinated plastic bags. Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill). Blue Glassware: Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste. Metallic body implants . Cardboard boxes with blue coloured markings. Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling. White Waste sharps including metals: Needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels or any other sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. Puncture proof and leak proof containers. Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 918 - 920

questions.question: Which color plastic bag would expired medications be discarded in according to the biomedical waste management guidelines?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Yellow Explanation Color Type of waste Example of waste Treatment and disposal Yellow Human anatomical waste. Animal anatomical waste. Soiled waste. Discarded or expired medicine. Microbiology, biotechnology, and other clinical laboratory waste. Chemical waste. Chemical liquid waste. Placenta. Post-operative body parts. Plaster of Paris (POP). Pathological waste. Cotton waste. Dressing materials. Beddings. Body fluid contaminated paper and cloth. Face mask, cap, shoe cover, and head cover. Cytotoxic, expired, and discarded medicines. Microbiology and biotechnology lab waste. Blood bag Vacutainers with blood Incineration. Plasma pyrolysis. Deep burial. Red Contaminated waste that is recyclable. Syringe without needles. Fixed needle syringes with their needle cut. IVset. Catheters. Gloves (soiled or unsoiled). Urine bag. Dialysis kit. IVbottles. Tubing's. Bottles. Vacutainers with needle cut. Vacutainers without blood. ELISA plate and vials not containing blood samples. Autoclaving or microwaving/ hydroclaving followed by shredding or mutilation and waste set to registered recyclers or for energy recovery/road making. Plastic waste should not be sent to landfill sites. White Waste Sharps Needles Syringes with fixed needles Blades Scalpers Trocar cannula Insulin pen needle Puncture-proof, Leak proof, Tamper proof containers Autoclaving or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding mutilation or encapsulation in a metal container or cement concrete Or sent for final disposal to iron foundries sanitary landfill or designated concrete waste sharp pit Blue Glassware or metallic body implants. Includes broken or discarded glass and metallic objects that are contaminated. Glass: Broken glass. Ampoules. Lab slide Metals: Nails. Metallic body implants. Scissors. Artificial pacemakers. Cardboard boxes with blue colored marking or blue colored puncture- proof and tamper-proof containers. Disinfection (cleaning with detergent and soaking in sodium hypochlorite) or autoclaving microwaving or hydroclaving and then sent for recycling. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 918-920

questions.question: Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) like Face shields, goggles, gloves and hazmat suits are disposed of in which colour bin?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Red Explanation: Most Personal protective equipment (PPE) is disposed of in a yellow bag. Shoe covers, head covers, disposable linen gowns, and masks are disposed in a yellow bag. (Option B) Face shields, goggles, gloves, and hazmat suits are disposed in a red bag as they are infected plastic waste. (Option C) No components of PPE are discarded under blue (Option A) or white (Option D) categories. COVID-19 biomedical waste management: Category Type of BMW Nature of Treatment Yellow Used masks, headcovers/caps, shoe covers, disposable linen gowns Waste contaminated with body/body fluids of COVID-19 patients. Incineration/plasma pyrolysis or deep burial. Red PPE such as goggles, face shields, splash proof aprons, plastic coveralls, Hazmat suits, nitrile gloves. Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill). White White sharps, including metals. Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation. Blue Glassware, metallic body implants. Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg:918-920

questions.question: How should vacutainers with blood be disposed in a healthcare facility?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Yellow bag Explanation Red Bag Yellow Bag Syringe without needles. Fixed needle syringes with their needle cut. IV set. Catheters. Gloves (soiled or unsoiled). IV bottles. Tubing's. Vacutainers with needle cut. Vacutainers without blood ELISA plate and vials not containing blood samples. Post-operative body parts. Plaster of Paris (POP). Pathological waste. Cotton waste. Dressing materials. Beddings. Body fluid contaminated paper and cloth. Face mask, cap, shoe cover and head cover. Cytotoxic, expired and discarded medicines. Blood bag Vacutainers with blood

questions.question: Which of the following chemical agents is used in the management of a mercury spill?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Sodium thiosulfate Explanation: Sodium thiosulphate reacts with mercury ions to form a complex that is less toxic and less soluble and hence used in the management of mercury spill Management of mercury spill: Switch off fans Remove anything metallic from one's body Wear PPE Never broom Use 2 X-ray films or 2 plastic boards to collect the mercury Dispose of decontaminated material in leak-proof, sealable plastic bags and dispose as mercury waste Clean floor with sodium thiosulphate Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25086412/ https://cdn.who.int/media/docs/default-source/wash-docume nts/wash-in-hcf/training-modules-in-health-care-waste-management/module-20---management-and-storage-of-merc ury-waste.pdf?sfvrsn=f1aeb810_2

questions.question: A rural clinic generates biomedical waste daily with no nearest biomedical waste treatment facility nearby. What is the most appropriate method for disposing of biomedical waste in this situation?

options.C: Use of disinfectants and dispose with municipal waste

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Deep Burial Explanation: Deep Burial: Indication: No common biomedical waste treatment facility (CBWTF) is available nearby. 2 metres deep. Common practice in PHCs. Biomedical waste should not be disposed of in regular landfills (Option A) due to its hazardous nature and potential for environmental contamination. The use of disinfectants and dispose with municipal waste (Option C) does not ensure proper treatment of biomedical waste and may lead to contamination of municipal waste streams, posing risks to waste handlers and the public. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 919

questions.question: A patient involved in an accident has sustained multiple injuries and a large amount of blood spills onto the floor. Which of the following is used for managing body spills?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 10% sodium hypochlorite solution used Explanation: Body spill refers to bodily fluids being accidentally spilled or released onto a surface, common in healthcare settings. Sodium hypochlorite is highly effective as a disinfectant against a broad spectrum of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi. Body spill management: 0.1% sodium hypochlorite solution used. 10% sodium hypochlorite solution used for larger spills. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15292898/

questions.question: Match the correct following parameters of autoclaving : Temperature Pressure Time a. Not less than 121°C i. 52 pounds/square inch 1. 60mins b. Not less than 135°C ii. 15 pounds/square inch 2. 30 mins c. Not less than 149°C iii. 31 pounds/square inch 3. 45 mins
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) c-i-2 Explanation: Different Autoclaving parameters: Temperature (°C) Pressure (psi) Time (minutes) Not less than 121°C 15 pounds/square inch 60 minutes Not less than 135°C 31 pounds/square inch 45 minutes Not less than 149°C 52 pounds/square inch 30 minutes Reference: https://cpcb.nic.in/uploads/Projects/Bio-Medical-Waste/Guidelines_healthcare_June_2018.pdf https://m pcb.mizoram.gov.in/uploads/attachments/f99c2afbe16ee2e6a874f8ea96329697/pages-32-bmw-standards.pdf

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false ?

options.A: The best way to dispose of sputum is incineration
options.B: Inertization includes mixing waste with cement and other substances before disposal
options.C: Contents of red bag should be incinerated
options.D: Screw Feed Technique is contraindicated for radiological waste

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Contents of the red bag should be incinerated. Explanation: The contents of red bags should not be incinerated as they contain cadmium which is explosive. Inertization: Mainly used for Pharmaceutical waste. Mixing waste with cement and other substances before disposal. (Option B) Mixture includes: 65% pharmaceutical work. 15% lime. 15% cement. 5% water. Screw feed technique: Biomedical waste + Auger + Heat + Rotate. Weight reduced by 20-25%. Volume reduced by 80%. Used for infectious waste and sharp waste. Contraindicated for radiological waste, cytological waste and pathological waste . (Option D) Incineration: High-temperature, dry oxidation process that reduces organic and combustible waste to inorganic, incombustible matter. Reduction of waste volume (85 - 95%) and weight (30%). The best way to dispose of sputum is incineration as it falls under infectious bodily waste. (Option A) Incineration is not suitable for Pressurized gas containers. Reactive chemicals Halogenated plastics (PVC). Waste with high mercury (eg thermometer) Sealed ampoules containing heavy metals and sharps. Contents of the red bag, as they contain cadmium which is explosive. (Option C) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Pages 916-918

questions.question: In a home quarantine setting for a COVID-19 patient, which coloured bags should be used for disposing of biomedical waste according to the specified protocol?

options.A: Red bag for used masks and tissues, yellow bag for rapid COVID-19 antigen test kits
options.B: Yellow bag for used masks and tissues, black bag for general waste
options.C: Black bag for used masks and tissues, yellow bag for rapid COVID-19 antigen test kits
options.D: Red bag for used masks and tissues, black bag for general waste

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Yellow bag for used masks and tissues, black bag for general waste Explanation: COVID-19 patients quarantined at home should use yellow bags for biomedical waste including used masks, tissues, and other items contaminated with body fluids. Segregation of Biomedical Waste COVID-19 waste disposal: Category 1 (Yellow Bags): Used masks, gloves, caps, goggles, shoe covers, disposable linen (bed sheets, pillow covers), etc., from isolation wards and quarantine areas. Category 2 (Red Bags): Used COVID-19 test kits, contaminated PPE, disposable medical devices, sharps, etc. Category 3 (Black Bags): General waste like food wrappers, paper, and other non-infectious items from quarantine areas. Segregation of COVID-19 waste at Point of Generation: Biomedical waste and general solid waste should be segregated immediately where it is generated, such as in wards or isolation rooms. Segregation of COVID-19 waste in Home Quarantine: COVID-19 patients quarantined at home should use two colored bags: Black Bag: For general waste like food wrappers, paper. Yellow Bag: For biomedical waste including used masks, tissues, and other items contaminated with body fluids. Reference: Revision 4 Guidelines for Handling, Treatment and Disposal of Waste Generated during Treatment/Diagnosis/ Quarantine of COVID-19 P

questions.question: Which term refers to the study and practice of improving the genetic quality of the human population through genetic manipulation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Eugenics Explanation: Eugenics is a field that seeks to improve the genetic composition of a human population by encouraging the reproduction of people with desirable traits (positive eugenics) and discouraging or preventing the reproduction of people with undesirable traits (negative eugenics). Positive Eugenics The goal is to increase the prevalence of desirable traits in the population over generations. This can be encouraged through various means such as: Financial and political stimuli Targeted demographic analyses In vitro fertilisation Egg transplants Gene cloning Negative Eugenics The objective is to reduce the frequency of hereditary disease and disability in the community. This could involve measures such as: Abortions Sterilizations Other methods of family planning Euthenics (Option A) focuses on improving human health and well-being by enhancing environmental and living conditions rather than altering genetic traits. This includes- prevention and removal of contagious diseases and parasites, environmentalism, education regarding home economics, sanitation and housing (environmental manipulation). Epigenetics (Option C) : Study of changes in gene expression caused by mechanisms other than changes in the underlying DNA sequence. Ethnology (Option D) : Scientific study of the origins and cultures of different races and ethnicities. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Ed. Pg. 954

questions.question: Which statement does not align with the Hardy-Weinberg Principle?

options.C: Allele frequencies vary within a species
options.D: Presence of random mating and a large population size

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Allele frequencies vary within a species Explanation: The Hardy-Weinberg law states that the genotype and allele frequencies remain constant in a population from generation to generation in the absence of evolutionary forces. It assumes that the population is stable and large, random mating occurs, no mutations affect the gene pool, no migration occurs, and natural selection does not act on the alleles. Hardy-Weinberg Principle: provides a quantitative framework for predicting genotype frequencies based on allele frequencies in a non-evolving population. The formula is expressed as: p 2 +2pq+q 2 = 1, where p and q represent the frequencies of two alleles (denoted as dominant and recessive), and p 2, 2pq,and q 2 represent the frequencies of the three possible genotypes. Frequency of homozygous dominant genotype + frequency of homozygous recessive genotype + frequency of heterozygous genotype = 1 Reference: Anecdotal, Historical and Critical Commentaries on Genetics: G. H. Hardy (1908) and Hardy–Weinberg Equilibrium - PMC The Hardy-Weinberg Principle | Learn Science at Scitable

questions.question: Which of the following factors can lead to deviations from the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium describes an idealised situation where population and gene pool remain constant over generations in the absence of evolutionary influences. Deviations from this equilibrium can occur due to various factors: Non-random mating (assortative mating) New mutations - Introducing new alleles into the gene pool Genetic drift - Random changes in allele frequencies due to chance events Gene flow - Natural selection - mortality selection, fecundity selection Small population Migration Dynamic populations Reference: K.Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Ed, Pg.954

questions.question: Which of the following best describes prospective genetic counselling? metabolism

options.A: Identifying heterozygous individuals for a specific defect through screening
options.B: Seeking genetic advice after a hereditary disorder has already occurred in the family
options.C: Discussing options such as contraception and termination of pregnancy based on genetic information
options.D: Counselling individuals with congenital anomalies, mental retardation, or inborn errors of

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Identifying heterozygous individuals for a specific defect through screening through screening processes for a genetic defect before any disorder occurs. Genetic counselling is a process that involves evaluating family history and genetic information to provide individuals and families with information about their genetic health and risks. It can be prospective or retrospective. Prospective Genetic Counselling Retrospective Genetic Counselling Seeking genetic advice before the occurrence of a hereditary disorder Seeking genetic advice after a hereditary disorder has occurred (Option B) Identify heterozygous individuals and explain the risk of having affected children if they marry another carrier, Prevention and risk assessment. Methods suggested: Contraception (Option C) Pregnancy termination (Option C) Sterilisation Applications: Sickle cell anaemia, thalassemia Applications: Counselling about Congenital abnormalities, Mental retardation, inborn errors of metabolism, psychiatric illnesses. (Option D) Prevention and risk assessment Provide guidance and management after the disorder has manifested Reference: K.Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Ed, Pg.955
